intro: Ipomopsis aggregata subsp. candida, commonly known as the white-flowered globe-mallow, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It is characterized by its showy, white to pale pink flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and it typically grows in dry, rocky habitats. It is part of the Malvaceae family, which includes mallows and hibiscus. The subspecies is distinguished by its lighter flower color compared to other varieties of Ipomopsis aggregata.
